title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
3.1 Content

Some introduction
Partial differential equations in geophysics
Finite Differences
Numerical integration
Integral equations and Method of Moments
Solving linear systems
Finite element method
Finite Volume method
High-performance computing
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
3.3 What should you know already?

Higher mathematics: differential equations, algebra (1.-2. BSc)
Experimental and theoretical physics: governing equations
Numerics for engineers (2. BSc)
Programming (1. BSc), Software development (3. BSc)
Geophysics: feeling for physical fields & methods
Electromagnetics (5. BSc), Theory EM,
now: Scientific programming, HPC, seismic imaging
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
3.4 Topics to be covered

recap on partial differential equations
(1D) heat equation: stationary and instationary (Geothermics course)
2D: magnetotellurics
3D DC modelling (content of Spitzer videos)
2D ground-penetrating radar (EM) and pressure waves (seismics)
excurse to hydrodynamic modelling
modelling the Eikonal equation (the travelling saleman)
exercises: code FD & FE by hand, use packages to obtain feeling
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
3.5 Literature

Haber (2015): Computational methods geophysical electromagnetics
Morra (2018): Pythonic Geodynamics - Implementations for fast computing, frei verfügbar unter https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-55682-6, zum Eintauchen ins Programmieren (MSc)
Warnick: Numerical Methods for Engineering : An Introduction Using MATLAB® and Computational Electromagnetics Examples Link
Igel (2007): Numerical modelling in geophysics, short course https://www.geophysik.uni-muenchen.de/~igel/nmg-short/ https://www.geophysik.uni-muenchen.de/~igel/downloads/
Logg et al. (2011): Automated Solution of Differential Equations by the Finite Element Method: Link
Press (2007): Numerical recipes: the art of scientific computing, https://numerical.recipes/book.html
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
3.6 Further links

pyGIMLi: Python Geophysical Inversion and Modelling Library https://pygimli.org
Geoscience.XYZ: https://geosci.xyz
Fenics handbook
Theory of electromagnetics https://ruboerner.github.io/ThEM/
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.1 Differential operators

single derivative in space \(\pdv{x}\) or time \(\pdv t\)
gradient \(\grad=(\pdv x, \pdv y, \pdv z)^T\)
divergence \(\div \vb F = \pdv{F_x}{x} + \pdv{F_y}{y} + \pdv{F_z}{z}\)




Gauss’: what’s in (volume) comes out (surface) \[\int_V \div\vb F\ dV = \iint_S \vb F \vdot \vb n\ dS\]




Gauss’s theorem in EM
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.2 Curl (rotation)

curl \(\curl \vb F = (\pdv{F_z}{y}-\pdv{F_y}{z}, \pdv{F_x}{z}-\pdv{F_z}{x}, \pdv{F_y}{x}-\pdv{F_x}{y})^T\)




Stoke: what goes around comes around \[\int_S \curl \vb F \vdot \vb dS = \iint_S \vb F \vdot \vb dl\]




Stokes’ theorem in EM







curls have no divergence: \(\div (\curl \vb F)=0\)




potential fields have no curl \(\curl (\grad u)=0\)
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.3 Numerical simulation
Mostly: solution of partial differential equations (PDEs) for either scalar (potentials) or vectorial (fields) quantities
PDE Types (\(u\)-function, \(f\)-source, \(a\)/\(c\)-parameter):

elliptic PDE: \(\nabla^2 u=f\)
parabolic PDE \(\nabla^2 u - a \frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=f\)
hyperbolic \(\nabla^2 u - c^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2}=f\) (plus diffusive term) \[\frac{\partial^2\ u}{{\partial x}^2} - c^2\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = 0\]
coupled \(\nabla\cdot u=f\) & \(u = K \nabla p=0\) (Darcy flow)
nonlinear \((\nabla u)^2=s^2\) (Eikonal equation)
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.4 Poisson equation
potential field \(u\) generates field \(\vec{F}=-\nabla u\)
causes some flow \(\vec{j}=a \vec{F}\)
\(a\) is some sort of conductivity (electric, hydraulic, thermal)
continuity of flow: divergence of total current \(\vb j + \vb j_s\) is zero
\[ \div (a \nabla u) = - \div \vb j_s \]
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.5 Darcy’s law


volumetric flow rate \(Q\) caused by gradient of pressure \(p\)
\[ Q = \frac{k A}{\mu L} \Delta p \]
\[\vb q = -\frac{k}{\mu} \nabla p \]
\[\div\vb q = -\div (k/\mu \grad p) = 0\]




Darcy’s law
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.6 The heat equation in 1D
sought: Temperature \(T\) as a function of space and time
heat flux density \(\vb q = \lambda\grad T\)
\(q\) in W/m², \(\lambda\) - heat conductivity/diffusivity in W/(m.K)
Fourier’s law: \(\pdv{T}{t} - a \nabla^2 T = s\) (\(s\) - heat source)
temperature conduction \(a=\frac{\lambda}{\rho c}\) (\(\rho\) - density, \(c\) - heat capacity)
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.7 Stokes equation
\[ \mu \nabla^2 \vb v - \grad p + f = 0 \]
\[\div\vb v = 0 \]
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.8 Navier-Stokes equations
(incompressible, uniform viscosity)
\[ \pdv{\vb u}{t} +(\vb u \vdot \grad) \vb u = \nu \nabla^2 \vb u - 1/\rho \grad p + f \]
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.9 Maxwell’s equations

Faraday’s law: currents & varying electric fields \(\Rightarrow\) magnetic field \[ \curl \vb H = \pdv{\vb D}{t} + \vb j \]
Ampere’s law: time-varying magnetic fields induce electric field \[ \curl\vb E = -\pdv{\vb B}{t}\]
\(\div\vb D = \varrho\) (charge \(\Rightarrow\)), \(\div\vb B = 0\) (no magnetic charge)
material laws \(\vb D = \epsilon \vb E\) and \(\vec B = \mu \vb H\)
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.10 Helmholtz equations
\[ \nabla^2 u + k^2 u = f \]
results from wavenumber decomposition of diffusion or wave equations
approach: \(\vb F = \vb{F_0}e^{\imath\omega t} \quad\Rightarrow\quad \pdv{\vb F}{t}=\imath\omega\vb F \quad\Rightarrow\quad \pdv[2]{\vb F}{t}=-\omega^2\vb F\)
\[ \nabla^2 \vb F - a \nabla_t \vb F - c^2 \nabla^2_t \vb F = 0 \]
\[ \Rightarrow \nabla^2\vb F - a\imath\omega\vb F + c^2 \omega^2\vb F = 0 \]
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text:
4.11 The eikonal equation
Describes first-arrival times \(t\) as a function of velocity (\(v\)) or slowness (\(s\))
\[ |\grad t| = s = 1/v \]
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations
text: 4.12 Taylor expansion
crumbs: 2  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 1: Foundations

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text: 4 Some mathematical background
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
4.1 Differential operators

single derivative in space \(\pdv{x}\) or time \(\pdv t\)
gradient \(\grad=(\pdv x, \pdv y, \pdv z)^T\)
divergence \(\div \vb F = \pdv{F_x}{x} + \pdv{F_y}{y} + \pdv{F_z}{z}\)




Gauss’: what’s in (volume) comes out (surface) \[\int_V \div\vb F\ dV = \iint_S \vb F \vdot \vb n\ dS\]




Gauss’s theorem in EM
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
4.2 Curl (rotation)

curl \(\curl \vb F = (\pdv{F_z}{y}-\pdv{F_y}{z}, \pdv{F_x}{z}-\pdv{F_z}{x}, \pdv{F_y}{x}-\pdv{F_x}{y})^T\)




Stoke: what goes around comes around \[\int_S \curl \vb F \vdot \vb dS = \iint_S \vb F \vdot \vb dl\]




Stokes’ theorem in EM







curls have no divergence: \(\div (\curl \vb F)=0\)




potential fields have no curl \(\curl (\grad u)=0\)
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.1 Partial differential equations (PDEs)
Mostly: solution of PDEs for either scalar (potentials) or vectorial (fields) quantities
PDE Types (\(u\)-function, \(f\)-source, \(a\)/\(c\)-parameter):

elliptic PDE: \(\nabla^2 u=f\)
parabolic PDE \(\nabla^2 u - a \frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=f\)
hyperbolic \(\nabla^2 u - c^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2}=f\) (plus diffusive term) \[\frac{\partial^2\ u}{{\partial x}^2} - c^2\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = 0\]
coupled \(\nabla\cdot u=f\) & \(u = K \nabla p=0\) (Darcy flow)
nonlinear \((\nabla u)^2=s^2\) (Eikonal equation)
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.2 Poisson equation
potential field \(u\) generates field \(\vec{F}=-\nabla u\)
causes some flow \(\vec{j}=a \vec{F}\)
\(a\) is some sort of conductivity (electric, hydraulic, thermal)
continuity of flow: divergence of total current \(\vb j + \vb j_s\) is zero
\[ \div (a \nabla u) = - \div \vb j_s \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.3 Darcy’s law


volumetric flow rate \(Q\) caused by gradient of pressure \(p\)
\[ Q = \frac{k A}{\mu L} \Delta p \]
\[\vb q = -\frac{k}{\mu} \nabla p \]
\[\div\vb q = -\div (k/\mu \grad p) = 0\]




Darcy’s law
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.4 The heat equation in 1D
sought: Temperature \(T\) as a function of space and time
heat flux density \(\vb q = \lambda\grad T\)
\(q\) in W/m², \(\lambda\) - heat conductivity/diffusivity in W/(m.K)
Fourier’s law: \(\pdv{T}{t} - a \nabla^2 T = s\) (\(s\) - heat source)
temperature conduction \(a=\frac{\lambda}{\rho c}\) (\(\rho\) - density, \(c\) - heat capacity)
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.5 Navier-Stokes equation
Stokes equation \[ \mu \nabla^2 \vb v - \grad p + f = 0 \]
\[\div\vb v = 0 \]
Navier-Stokes equation (incompressible, uniform viscosity)
\[ \pdv{\vb u}{t} +(\vb u \vdot \grad) \vb u = \nu \nabla^2 \vb u - 1/\rho \grad p + f \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.6 Maxwell’s equations

Faraday’s law: currents & varying electric fields \(\Rightarrow\) magnetic field \[ \curl \vb H = \pdv{\vb D}{t} + \vb j \]
Ampere’s law: time-varying magnetic fields induce electric field \[ \curl\vb E = -\pdv{\vb B}{t}\]
\(\div\vb D = \varrho\) (charge \(\Rightarrow\)), \(\div\vb B = 0\) (no magnetic charge)
material laws \(\vb D = \epsilon \vb E\) and \(\vec B = \mu \vb H\)
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.7 Helmholtz equations
\[ \nabla^2 \vb F + k^2 \vb F = f \]
results from wavenumber decomposition of diffusion or wave equations
approach: \(\vb F = \vb{F_0}e^{\imath\omega t} \quad\Rightarrow\quad \pdv{\vb F}{t}=\imath\omega\vb F \quad\Rightarrow\quad \pdv[2]{\vb F}{t}=-\omega^2\vb F\)
\[ \nabla^2 \vb F - a \nabla_t \vb F - c^2 \nabla^2_t \vb F = 0 \]
\[ \Rightarrow \nabla^2\vb F - a\imath\omega\vb F + c^2 \omega^2\vb F = 0 \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
5.8 The Eikonal equation
Describes first-arrival times \(t\) as a function of velocity (\(v\)) or slowness (\(s\))
\[ |\grad t| = s = 1/v \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.1 Taylor expansion
Assume the Poisson equation \[\div(a\grad u)=f\]
Taylor expansion \[f(x)=f(x_0)+f'(x0)(x-x_0)+f''(x_0)(x-x_0)^2/2\]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.2 Finite differences






Approximate derivative operators by differences



\[ \pdv{u}{x}\approx\frac{\Delta u}{\Delta x} \]


and solution \(u\) by finite values \(u_i\) at points \(x_i\), e.g. \[ \dv*{u}{x}_{2.5} := (u_3-u_2) / (x_3-x_2) \]

\[\pdv[2]{u_3}{x}\approx
\frac{\dv*{u}{x}_{3.5}-\dv*{u}{x}_{2.5}}{(x_4-x_2)/2}
= \frac{(u_4-u_3)/(x_4-x_3)-(u_3-u_2)/(x_3-x_2)}{(x_4-x_2)/2} \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.3 Difference stencil
Assumption: equidistant discretization \(\Delta x\), conductivity 1
1st derivative: \([-1, +1] / dx\), 2nd derivative \([+1, -2, +1] / dx^2\)
Matrix-Vector product \(\vb{A}\cdot\vb{u}=\vb{f}\) with
\[ \vb{A} = \begin{bmatrix}   
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
0 & +1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & \ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix}  \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
section: 6.4 FDM on the general Poisson equation
text:
6.4 FDM on the general Poisson equation
Assume the Poisson equation \[\div(a\grad u)=f\]
\[ \pdv{(a \dv*{u})}{z} = a\pdv[2]{u}{z} + \pdv{a}{z} \pdv{u}{z}  \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.5 Boundary conditions
Dirichlet conditions: \(u_0=u_B\) (homogeneous if 0)
Neumann conditions (homogeneous if 0) \[ \pdv*{u}{x}_0=g_B \]
Mixed boundary conditions \(u_0+\alpha du_0/dx=\gamma\)
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.6 Dirichlet BC implementation way 1
\(u_0 = u_B\)
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
+1 & 0 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & \ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} u_B\\ f_1 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix}  \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.7 Dirichlet BC implementation way 2
\(u_B - 2 u_1 + u_3 = f_1\)
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
-2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} f_1 - u_B\\ f_2 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix} \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.8 Neumann BC implementation way 1
\[ u_1 - u_0 = g_B\]
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
-1 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\ldots & \ldots & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} f_0+g_B\\ f_1 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix}  \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
6.9 Neumann BC implementation way 2
\[u_0 - 2 u_1+u_2 = f_1 \qquad u_1 - u_0 = g_B \Rightarrow u_2-u_1=f_1+g_B \] 
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
-1 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} f_1 + g_B\\ f_2 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix} \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
7.1 Heat transfer in 1D
\[ \pdv{T}{t} - a \pdv[2]{T}{z} = 0 \]
with the periodic boundary conditions:

\(T(z=0,t)=T_0 + \Delta T \sin \omega t\) (daily/yearly cycle)
\(\pdv{T}{z}(z=z_1) = 0\) (no change at depth)

and the initial condition \(T(z, t=0)=\sin \pi z\) has the analytical solution \[ T(z, t) = \Delta T e^{-\pi^2 t} \sin \pi z \]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
7.2 Explicit methods
\[ \pdv{T}{t} - a \pdv[2]{T}{z} = 0 \]
Solve Poisson equation \(\div(a\grad u)=f\)
for every time step \(i\) (using FDM, FEM, FVM etc.)
Finite-difference step in time: update field by \[ T_{i+1} = T_i + a \pdv[2]{u}{z} \cdot \Delta t\]
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text:
7.3 Implicit methods
next lecture
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences
text: 7.4 Mixed methods
crumbs: 3  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 2: Finite Differences

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text: 5 Recap and exercise
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.1 Task: solve Poisson equation
\[\div(a\grad u)=f\]
(stationary) potential field, e.g., temperature, flux, current
simplest method: Finite differences
FD: Approximate derivative operators by differences using finite values \(u_i\) at points \(x_i\), e.g. a
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.2 Unit solution
2nd derivative \([+1, -2, +1]\) \(\Rightarrow\) \(\vb{A}\cdot\vb{u}=\vb{f}\) with the stiffness matrix
\[ \vb{A} = \begin{bmatrix}   
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
0 & +1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & \ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix}  \]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.3 Finite difference stencil









compute each value (red) with the help of its neighbors (blue)
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.4 Dirichlet boundary conditions
\(u_B - 2 u_1 + u_3 = f_1\)
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
-2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} f_1 - u_B\\ f_2 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix} \]
no change in coefficients, \(u_B\) on rhs act as outer source
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.5 Neumann boundary conditions
\[u_0 - 2 u_1+u_2 = f_1 \qquad u_1 - u_0 = g_B \Rightarrow u_2-u_1=f_1+g_B \] 
\[ \begin{bmatrix}   
-1 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & &  \\
+1 & -2 & +1 & 0 & \ldots & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots &  \\
\ldots & 0 & +1 & -2 & +1
\end{bmatrix} \cdot\vb{u} =
\begin{bmatrix} f_1 + g_B\\ f_2 \\ \vdots \\ f_N \end{bmatrix} \]
change in self-coupling, \(g_B\) on rhs adds to source
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.6 Tasks

Create a stiffness matrix for unit quantities
Implement Dirichlet BC on one and Neumann on other side
Solve system for different right-hand sides:

no source at all
single source in the middle or at the boundary
several sources with different strengths (& signs)
source on part of the domain

Alwas plot the solution and itsLaplacian
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.7 The general case
\(\Delta x \ne 1\) & \(a \ne 1\)
\(a \pdv{u}{x}\)
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
5.8 Tasks

Derive the coefficiencs for the general case
Write a function implementing the general case
Divide the “subsurface” in regions with different \(a\)
Compute the solution for different source fields
Use a non-equidistant discretisation
Always plot solution along with source and Laplacian
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
6.1 Heat transfer in 1D
\[ \pdv{T}{t} - a \pdv[2]{T}{z} = 0 \]
with the periodic boundary conditions: * \(T(z=0,t)=T_0 + \Delta T \sin \omega t\) (daily/yearly cycle) * \(\pdv{T}{z}(z=z_1) = 0\) (no change at depth) and the initial condition \(T(z, t=0)=\sin \pi z\) has the analytical solution \[ T(z, t) = \Delta T e^{-\pi^2 t} \sin \pi z \]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text: 6.2 FD stencil
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
6.3 Explicit methods
\[ \pdv{T}{t} - a \pdv[2]{T}{z} = 0 \]
Finite-difference approximation
\[ \pdv{T}{t}^n \approx \frac{T^{n+1}-T^n}{\Delta t} = a \pdv[2]{T}{z} ^n \]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
6.4 Explicit
Solve Poisson equation \(\div(a\grad u)=f\)
for every time step \(i\) (using FDM, FEM, FVM etc.)
Finite-difference step in time: update field by \[ T_{i+1} = T_i + a \pdv[2]{u}{z} \cdot \Delta t\]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
6.5 Implicit methods
\[ \pdv{T}{t}^n \approx \frac{T^{n+1}-T^n}{\Delta t} = a \pdv[2]{T}{z} ^{n+1} \]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation

title: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
text:
6.6 Mixed - Crank-Nicholson method
\[ \pdv{T}{t}^n \approx \frac{T^{n+1}-T^n}{\Delta t} = \frac12 a \pdv[2]{T}{z} ^n + \frac12 a \pdv[2]{T}{z} ^{n+1} \]
crumbs: 4  Numerical Simulation Methods in Geophysics, Part 3: FD Implementation
